content.html: I propose in the present memoir to consider the theory of matrices, and in connection therewith the theory of linear transformations.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: A matrix is formed from a rectangular array of quantities, arranged in rows and columns.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Two matrices may be said to be equal when the corresponding elements are equal.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The addition of matrices is effected by adding together the corresponding elements.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The product of two matrices is defined by a law of combination which depends upon the multiplication and addition of the elements.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: If we denote the matrix by A, and the matrix by B, the product AB is in general different from BA.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: There exists a particular matrix, which may be called the unit-matrix, such that its product with any other matrix leaves that matrix unaltered.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The determinant of a matrix is a function of its elements, and plays an essential part in the theory.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The determinant vanishes when the rows or columns are linearly dependent.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: If the determinant of a matrix does not vanish, the matrix possesses an inverse.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The inverse matrix is that matrix which, when multiplied with the original matrix, produces the unit-matrix.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Matrices may be considered as symbols of linear substitutions.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The composition of two linear transformations corresponds to the multiplication of their matrices.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: A matrix of the form \( \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \) represents a linear transformation in two variables.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The eigenvalues of a matrix are obtained by solving the equation \( \det(A - \lambda I) = 0 \).

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The characteristic equation expresses a fundamental relation satisfied by the matrix itself.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic equation.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The theory of matrices thus supplies a general method for the investigation of linear transformations.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Matrices admit of powers, positive and negative, according to the laws of multiplication.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: The generality of the method renders it applicable to a wide class of algebraical investigations.

work.title: A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices

content.html: Marx devoted considerable effort during the last years of his life to the study of mathematics, especially the foundations of differential calculus. These studies were not incidental but reflected a deeper concern with the logical structure of scientific reasoning.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: For Marx, mathematics was not politically neutral. Its development was shaped by historical and social forces, and its concepts reflected the dialectical processes that governed material reality.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The problem of infinitesimals had long troubled mathematicians. Marx was particularly interested in the logical contradictions embedded in their early formulations and sought to expose their conceptual weaknesses.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: In examining expressions such as \(\frac{dy}{dx}\), Marx questioned whether infinitesimals were genuine quantities or merely symbolic devices masking deeper logical transformations.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Marx regarded the transition from finite difference quotients to derivatives as an example of dialectical transformation, where quantitative change gives rise to qualitative difference.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The limit concept, formalized in the nineteenth century, resolved many earlier ambiguities surrounding infinitesimals. Yet Marx’s notebooks reveal that he was less concerned with formalism than with logical clarity.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Mao later embraced mathematics as a tool of revolutionary transformation, insisting that theory must be united with practice. Mathematical education became part of broader ideological reform.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The politics of infinitesimals thus extended beyond technical mathematics. They became emblematic of debates over abstraction, rigor, and the social function of science.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Expressions like \(\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}\) represent the culmination of centuries of effort to clarify the foundations of calculus.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Nonstandard analysis later restored infinitesimals to mathematics in a rigorous way, demonstrating that earlier conceptual difficulties could be overcome within a new logical framework.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Mathematics, in this context, becomes a field in which philosophical commitments are enacted through technical choices about definition, proof, and rigor.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The historical study of mathematics reveals that its development is neither linear nor inevitable. It is shaped by intellectual struggle, cultural context, and philosophical debate.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Marx regarded questions about the foundations of the differential calculus as a “touchstone of the application of the method of materialist dialectics to mathematics.”

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: During the Cultural Revolution, mathematics was suspect for being too abstract, aloof from the concerns of the common man and the struggle to meet the basic needs of daily life in a still largely agrarian society.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Marx used dialectical materialism to evaluate the history of the calculus, and was especially critical of what he took to be its idealistic, metaphysical foundations.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Marx emphasized that the differential does not arise from the mere neglect of higher powers of infinitesimals, but from a logical transformation in which the ratio \(\Delta y / \Delta x\) passes to its limit and becomes \(dy/dx\).

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: According to Bishop Berkeley, the differential \(dx\) was “the ghost of a departed quantity.”

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The familiar example \(y = x^3\) served repeatedly as a test case for interpreting the derivative and distinguishing between difference quotients \(\Delta y / \Delta x\) and differentials \(dy/dx\).

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: Nonstandard analysis constructs a mathematical system based on infinitesimals, providing another interpretation of the calculus distinct from the method of limits.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The core of nonstandard analysis shows there is an infinitesimal between zero and any positive number, using the methods of mathematical logic.

work.title: Marx, Mao and Mathematics: The Politics of Infinitesimals

content.html: The reflections which form the subject of this little treatise date from the autumn of the year 1858. At that time I felt more keenly than ever before the lack of a truly scientific foundation for arithmetic. This feeling of dissatisfaction was so overpowering that I formed the fixed resolve to reflect until I had found a purely arithmetical and completely rigorous foundation for the principles of infinitesimal analysis.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: By arithmetic I understand the science of numbers. The development of arithmetic depends upon the creation of the infinite sequence of positive integers. From this arise the negative and rational numbers, through the demand that subtraction and division shall always be possible.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: The rational numbers form an ordered field; but they do not suffice to express every magnitude. There exist magnitudes which cannot be expressed by rational numbers, although they are determined by rational relations.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html:
Let D be a positive integer which is not the square of an integer. Then there exists a positive integer \(\lambda\) such that

\[ \lambda^2 < D < (\lambda + 1)^2. \]

No rational number whose square equals D exists. Thus the rational numbers are insufficient to represent all magnitudes.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If all points of a straight line fall into two classes such that every point of the first class lies to the left of every point of the second class, then there exists one and only one point which produces this division of all points into two classes.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: Every cut of the rational numbers into two classes, such that every number of the first class is less than every number of the second, determines either a rational or an irrational number.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: Whenever a cut is given which is not produced by a rational number, we create a new number corresponding to this cut, which we call an irrational number. Thus the domain of rational numbers is extended to a new domain of numbers.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: The totality of all real numbers forms a complete ordered field. Between any two distinct real numbers there exist infinitely many others.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are real numbers corresponding to cuts \((A_1, A_2)\) and \((B_1, B_2)\), then their sum \(\gamma = \alpha + \beta\) is defined by a corresponding cut \((C_1, C_2)\).

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: The order of the real numbers is such that if \(\alpha > \beta\) and \(\beta > \gamma\), then \(\alpha > \gamma\). This order extends that of the rational numbers without contradiction.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If a variable magnitude increases continuously but remains bounded above, then it approaches a limit. This theorem is equivalent to the principle of continuity of the real numbers.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: The essence of continuity lies in the completeness of the number system. The arithmetical conception of the real numbers renders the appeal to geometric intuition unnecessary for the foundation of analysis.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: I regard the whole of arithmetic as a necessary or at least natural consequence of the simplest arithmetical act, that of counting; and counting itself is nothing other than the successive creation of the infinite series of positive integers.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: I find the essence of continuity in the following principle: If all points of a straight line fall into two classes such that every point of the first lies to the left of every point of the second, then there exists one and only one point which produces this division.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: In the property that not all cuts are produced by rational numbers consists the incompleteness or discontinuity of the domain \(\mathbb{Q}\).

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: Whenever a cut \((A_1, A_2)\) is given which is not produced by a rational number, we create a new number \(\alpha\), which we call an irrational number, and which we regard as completely defined by this cut.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If the system of real numbers \(\mathbb{R}\) is divided into two classes \(\mathcal{A}_1\) and \(\mathcal{A}_2\) such that every number \(\alpha_1\) in \(\mathcal{A}_1\) is less than every number \(\alpha_2\) in \(\mathcal{A}_2\), then there exists one and only one number \(\alpha\) which produces this division.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: To define the sum \(\gamma = \alpha + \beta\), it suffices to define the cut \((C_1, C_2)\) which corresponds to it, reducing the operation entirely to operations among rational numbers.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If a variable magnitude increases continuously but remains bounded, then it approaches a limit. This theorem is equivalent to the principle of continuity.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If S be a divisor of N, then there is a conjugate divisor S' such that SS' = N. Thus we see that the number of divisors from 1 to \( \sqrt{N} \) is equal to the number of divisors from \( \sqrt{N} \) to N.

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: Let \( N = p_1^{a_1} p_2^{a_2} \dots p_n^{a_n} \), where \( p_1, p_2, \dots, p_n \) are primes. Then it is easy to see that \( d(N) = (1+a_1)(1+a_2)\dots(1+a_n) \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: Since the arithmetic mean of unequal positive numbers is always greater than their geometric mean, we obtain inequalities which give a superior limit for \( d(N) \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: If \( p \) be the largest prime not exceeding \( x \), then bounds for \( d(N) \) may be expressed in terms of the product \( \log 2 \log 3 \log 5 \dots \log p \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: The symbol \( O \) is used in the following sense: \( f(x) = O(\phi(x)) \) means that there is a positive constant \( K \) such that \( |f(x)| \leq K \phi(x) \) for all sufficiently large values of \( x \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

posts.caption: Fermat is sometimes considered the founder of modern number theory.

posts.caption: Set inclusions between the natural numbers (\( \mathbb{N} \)), the integers (\( \mathbb{Z} \)), the rational numbers (\( \mathbb{Q} \)), the real numbers (\( \mathbb{R} \)), and the complex numbers (\( \mathbb{C} \)).

work.title: Real number

posts.caption: Real numbers \( \mathbb{R} \) include the rational numbers \( \mathbb{Q} \), which include the integers \( \mathbb{Z} \), which in turn include the natural numbers \( \mathbb{N} \).

authors.name: Arthur Cayley
authors.bio: English mathematician who founded the abstract theory of matrices.

authors.name: Joseph W. Dauben
authors.bio: Historian of mathematics known for work on Marx, Mao, and the politics of infinitesimals.

authors.name: Richard Dedekind
authors.bio: German mathematician who gave a rigorous arithmetical construction of the real numbers via cuts.

authors.name: Srinivasa Ramanujan
authors.bio: Indian mathematician known for extraordinary contributions to number theory, infinite series, and asymptotic formulas.

authors.bio: Free online encyclopedia containing collaboratively written and edited articles.

ramanujan.bio: Indian mathematician known for extraordinary contributions to number theory, infinite series, and asymptotic formulas.

At that time I felt more keenly than ever before the lack of a truly scientific foundation for arithmetic. This feeling of dissatisfaction was so overpowering that I formed the fixed resolve to reflect until I had found a purely arithmetical and completely rigorous foundation for the principles of infinitesimal analysis.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: The order of the real numbers is such that if \(\alpha > \beta\) and \(\beta > \gamma\), then \(\alpha > \gamma\). This order extends that of the rational numbers without contradiction.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: In the property that not all cuts are produced by rational numbers consists the incompleteness or discontinuity of the domain \(\mathbb{Q}\).

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: Whenever a cut \((A_1, A_2)\) is given which is not produced by a rational number, we create a new number \(\alpha\), which we call an irrational number, and which we regard as completely defined by this cut.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If the system of real numbers \(\mathbb{R}\) is divided into two classes \(\mathcal{A}_1\) and \(\mathcal{A}_2\) such that every number \(\alpha_1\) in \(\mathcal{A}_1\) is less than every number \(\alpha_2\) in \(\mathcal{A}_2\), then there exists one and only one number \(\alpha\) which produces this division.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: To define the sum \(\gamma = \alpha + \beta\), it suffices to define the cut \((C_1, C_2)\) which corresponds to it, reducing the operation entirely to operations among rational numbers.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If a variable magnitude increases continuously but remains bounded, then it approaches a limit. This theorem is equivalent to the principle of continuity.

work.title: Continuity and Irrational Numbers

content.html: If S be a divisor of N, then there is a conjugate divisor S' such that SS' = N. Thus we see that the number of divisors from 1 to \( \sqrt{N} \) is equal to the number of divisors from \( \sqrt{N} \) to N.

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: Let \( N = p_1^{a_1} p_2^{a_2} \dots p_n^{a_n} \), where \( p_1, p_2, \dots, p_n \) are primes. Then it is easy to see that \( d(N) = (1+a_1)(1+a_2)\dots(1+a_n) \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: Since the arithmetic mean of unequal positive numbers is always greater than their geometric mean, we obtain inequalities which give a superior limit for \( d(N) \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: If \( p \) be the largest prime not exceeding \( x \), then bounds for \( d(N) \) may be expressed in terms of the product \( \log 2 \log 3 \log 5 \dots \log p \).

work.title: On the Number of Divisors of a Number

content.html: The symbol \( O \) is used in the following sense: \( f(x) = O(\phi(x)) \) means that there is a positive constant \( K \) such that \( |f(x)| \leq K \phi(x) \) for all sufficiently large values of \( x \).
